newsitem.title: USA: France's Lemierre sees EMU starting on time.
newsitem.headline: France's Lemierre sees EMU starting on time.

text.p: French Treasury Director Jean Lemierre said on Tuesday that France expected European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) would start on time and France would be among the founding members.
"We believe that the timetable for EMU will be met, that is to say the first of January 1999," Lemierre said during a luncheon at a European Institute conference here.

Lemierre said France would be ready in the first wave not only because of the specific benefits of EMU, but also because efforts which are required for entry into EMU are to be made whether or not there is a single currency in Europe.
The starting date also meets France's normal economic program, he said.
Lemierre refused to speculate about which other countries would be included in the first wave of EMU membership. "I'm not going to speak for other countries," he said.
One of the key standards for qualifying for EMU requires countries to reduce their public budget deficits to 3.0 percent of gross domestic product this year.
"This year we'll reach the 3.0 percent criteria," Lemierre said. He noted the European Commission and International Monetary Fund considered this a credible objective.
